description: From Middle French effacer (“erase”), from Old French esfacier (“remove the face”).

verbs.description: efface (third-person singular simple present effaces, present participle effacing, simple past and past participle effaced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To erase (as anything impressed or inscribed upon a surface); to render illegible or indiscernible.
examples: Do not efface what I've written on the chalkboard.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to disappear as if by rubbing out or striking out.
examples: Some people like to efface their own memories with alcohol.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To make oneself inobtrusive as if due to modesty or diffidence.
examples: Many people seem shy, but they really just efface for meekness.

entries.meaning: (medicine) Of the cervix during pregnancy, to thin and stretch in preparation for labor.
examples: Some females efface 75% by the 39th week of pregnancy.
